channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,179 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: IHT Special: Libya Looks to Spain as Model for State-Building
item.description: A dozen Libyans from grassroots, pro-democracy groups attended sessions in Madrid this month on Spain’s post-dictatorial transition to democracy.
item.dc:creator: By MIKE ELKIN

item.title: IHT Special: Morocco Slow to Enforce Laws on Women's Rights
item.description: Conservative judges in Morocco have been finding ways around Morocco's liberalized code of family law, which gave women more rights regarding divorce, polygamy and the age of marriage.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI

item.title: At Cardozo Law School, Outrage Over Choice to Honor President Carter
item.description: The editors of a journal at Yeshiva University’s law school have set off a major conflict by bestowing a peace award on former President Jimmy Carter, who has harshly criticized Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ARIEL KAMINER
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in Manhattan.

item.title: Song by Willie Colón Targets Nicolás Maduro in Venezuela
item.description: As Venezuelans prepare to vote on Sunday for a new president, Willie Colón, a salsa star, has contributed a song that skewers Nicolás Maduro, picked by Hugo Chávez to be his successor.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolás Maduro, center, a contender for the Venezuelan presidency, is the target of a song by Willie Colón, a Bronx-born salsa performer.

item.title: U.S. and South Korea Gird for North Missile Test
item.description: American and South Korean troops increased alert levels on Wednesday as South Korea’s foreign minister warned that the North could launch its medium-range Musudan missile “any time from now.”
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: American soldiers prepared for an exercise on Wednesday during their annual military drills with South Korea in Yeoncheon, near the border with North Korea.

item.title: The Lede: Leaked Report to Egypt’s President Implicates Army in Torture and Killing of Civilians
item.description: The document, which is in Arabic, cites specific cases of civilian disappearances, torture and death at the hands of Egypt’s military.
item.dc:creator: By LIAM STACK

item.title: Death of Khiraullah Janan, Related to Karzai Adviser, Adds to Tensions With Afghan Military
item.description: The brother-in-law of an adviser to President Hamid Karzai was killed in a raid by Afghan commandos and American advisers, adding to growing tensions in the region.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Delay on China Avian Flu Announcement Questioned
item.description: Questions are being raised about the methods Chinese officials used to test for the deadly strain of avian influenza and the delay in reporting the first known human case.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: A worker at a clinic for H7N9 bird flu at a hospital in Shanghai.

item.title: Horse Meat Problems Resurface Across Europe
item.description: The scandal over horse meat sold as beef re-emerged with a Dutch alert about 50,000 tons of meat sold in Europe and a recall of a product in Britain containing a veterinary drug.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: European Countries Move to Toughen Stance on Tax Evasion
item.description: President François Hollande of France announced the creation of a new special prosecutor position to pursue corruption and tax fraud, and vowed to eradicate tax havens.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: President Francois Hollande of France announced the move against tax havens in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: WORLD: Parliament Debates Thatcher
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron and members of Parliament pay tribute to Margaret Thatcher.

item.title: Arab Israeli Man Accused of Joining Syrian Rebels
item.description: Israel’s internal security agency charged Hikmat Massarwa with crimes including contact with a foreign agent after he traveled to Syria to fight alongside the rebels.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Thatcher as Theater: A Prime Minister Playwrights Couldn’t Resist
item.description: Five seminal British plays that would never have come about without Margaret Thatcher.
item.dc:creator: By MATT WOLF
item.media:description: Haydn Gwyne plays Margaret Thatcher and Helen Mirren is Queen Elizabeth II in "The Audience" by Peter Morgan on stage in London.

item.title: At War Blog: 10 Mistakes of the Iraq War
item.description: An interview with Colonel Ted Spain, who was deployed to Iraq as the commander of the 18th Military Police Brigade.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HANNAH C. MURPHY

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Spokesman Quits After French Rabbi Admits Plagiarism
item.description: Rabbi Moché Lewin resigned as spokesman after France’s chief rabbi acknowledged lying about his academic credentials.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Finland Apologizes for ‘Incorrect’ Putin Blacklisting
item.description: Finland apologized to Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday after its police accidentally put him on a blacklist of people with connections to criminal activity.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 10
item.description: An artisan works on freshly dyed strands of multicolored thread used in Hindu rituals, in Uttar Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: An artisan hanging freshly dyed strands of multicolored thread used in Hindu rituals, at Lalgopalganj, a town in Allahabad district of Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: India Ink: Dozens Injured in Tamil Nadu Train Accident
item.description: Nearly half the cars of a 24 car train derailed, one killed.
item.dc:creator: By ANUPAMA CHANDRASEKARAN
item.media:description: Rescue workers gathered at the site of a train accident at Sitheri in Tamil Nadu on Wednesday.

item.title: Lawmakers Debate Thatcher Legacy
item.description: A parliamentary session called to commemorate Mrs. Thatcher was unusual because of its expected duration and because lawmakers were recalled from recess.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL

item.title: The Lede: Dutch Reporter Spends Night in Cairo Jail After Citizen’s Arrest
item.description: A Dutch reporter in Cairo spent Monday night in jail after the owner of a cafe detained her on suspicion of “spreading European culture” and endangering Egypt’s national security by looking for subjects to interview.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Pakistan Police Guarding Polio Workers Are Attacked
item.description: There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, but the Pakistani Taliban have repeatedly targeted health workers vaccinating against polio.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Europe Urged to Make a U-Turn on Austerity
item.description: George Soros and Jacob Lew are among those calling for Europe’s leaders to rethink stringent financial policies that they claim are making a bad economic situation worse.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: The Treasury secretary, Jacob Lew, left, with Pierre Moscovici, the French finance minister. France, facing a slump, has said it would welcome a looser approach.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Missiles and Memorial Stones: Figuring Out North Korea and China
item.description: Amid talk of China’s position on North Korea shifting, an ancient archeological find may point to its real interests in the region, some Koreans believe.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A Chinese man throwing a rock for his dog to catch on the bank of the Yalu River, which divides China from North Korea. The far bank is North Korean territory.

item.title: Letter from India: Politicians Courting the Privileged
item.description: The Indian middle-class awakening has quickly evolved from a rage against politics to a passion for politics.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH
